title: Problem Overview
content: **Erdős Problem #286**: Can 1 be expressed as a sum of k distinct unit fractions with denominators in an interval of width (e-1+o(1))k? Croot (2001) proved the answer is yes.
mathContext: 1 = 1/n₁ + ... + 1/nₖ with all nᵢ in [a, a + (e-1)k]. The constant e-1 ≈ 1.718 is optimal.

title: Core Definitions
content: **IsUnitFractionSum**: A set S of positive integers with ∑(1/n) = q. **SumsToOne**: When S sums to 1. **NatInterval**: The interval [a,b] in ℕ.
mathContext: These definitions capture unit fraction representations and interval constraints.

title: Main Predicate
content: **HasShortIntervalRepresentation(k, width)**: There exist k positive integers in an interval of given width whose reciprocals sum to 1.
mathContext: The core question: for which k and width does such a representation exist?

title: Verified Examples
mathContext: Concrete examples verified with native_decide, showing the problem is satisfiable for small k.

title: Erdős-Graham Constant
content: **ErdosGrahamConstant = e - 1 ≈ 1.718**: The asymptotically optimal width coefficient. We prove 1.7 < e-1 < 1.72 using Mathlib's exp bounds.
mathContext: Real.exp_one_gt_d9 and Real.exp_one_lt_d9 give tight bounds on e.

title: Croot's Theorem
content: **Croot (2001)**: For all sufficiently large k, there exists a representation with interval width at most (e-1+ε)k. The constant e-1 is asymptotically tight.
mathContext: croot_theorem states the upper bound; optimality states the matching lower bound.

title: Egyptian Fractions
content: **IsEgyptianFraction**: A representation of q as a sum of distinct unit fractions. The greedy algorithm always finds such a representation, but doesn't minimize interval width.
mathContext: Every positive rational has an Egyptian fraction representation, but finding one with minimal interval width is the harder question.
